sections.title: Introduction to SQL
sections.brief: An introduction to SQL (Structured Query Language), a standardized language for managing data in relational database management systems (RDBMS). It covers the basics of SQL and its capabilities, including querying, retrieving, inserting, updating, and deleting data.

subsections.title: Data Definition Language (DDL)
subsections.brief: Covers Data Definition Language (DDL) which manages table and index structure. Explains CREATE, ALTER, RENAME, and DROP statements for creating, modifying, and deleting database objects.

subsections.title: Data Manipulation Language (DML)
subsections.brief: Covers Data Manipulation Language (DML) used for adding, updating, and deleting data. Explains the CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) and their corresponding SQL statements (INSERT INTO, SELECT, UPDATE, DELETE).

sections.title: Introduction to SQL Server
sections.brief: An introduction to Microsoft SQL Server and its components, including the Database Engine and Management Studio. Explains the different editions of SQL Server and the use of T-SQL (Transact-SQL).

subsections.title: SQL Server Management Studio
subsections.brief: Introduces SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS), a GUI tool for managing SQL Server. Describes the Object Explorer and query windows, and how to use them for database administration and querying.

sections.title: CREATE TABLE
sections.brief: Explains the CREATE TABLE statement for creating tables in a database. Covers data types, constraints, and best practices for table design.

subsections.title: Database Modelling
subsections.brief: Emphasizes the importance of database modeling before implementation. Introduces database modeling tools like ERwin and demonstrates how to transfer models to SQL Server.

subsections.title: Create Tables using the Designer Tools
subsections.brief: Demonstrates how to create tables using the designer tools in SQL Server Management Studio, providing a visual alternative to writing SQL scripts.

subsections.title: SQL Constraints
subsections.brief: Explains SQL constraints used to limit the type of data in a table. Covers PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, NOT NULL, UNIQUE, CHECK, DEFAULT, and IDENTITY constraints.

subsections.title: ALTER TABLE
subsections.brief: Explains the ALTER TABLE statement for modifying existing tables. Covers adding, deleting, and modifying columns, and demonstrates how to create robust database scripts using CREATE TABLE and ALTER TABLE together.

sections.title: INSERT INTO
sections.brief: Explains the INSERT INTO statement for inserting new rows into a table. Covers two forms of the statement, inserting data into specific columns, and using the designer tools for data insertion.

sections.title: UPDATE
sections.brief: Explains the UPDATE statement for updating existing records in a table. Emphasizes the importance of the WHERE clause and demonstrates how to update data using the designer tools.

sections.title: DELETE
sections.brief: Explains the DELETE statement for deleting rows from a table. Emphasizes the importance of the WHERE clause and demonstrates how to delete data using the designer tools.

sections.title: SELECT
sections.brief: Explains the SELECT statement for retrieving data from a database. Covers selecting specific columns, the ORDER BY keyword, SELECT DISTINCT, the WHERE clause, wildcards, AND & OR operators, SELECT TOP, aliases, and joins.

subsections.title: The ORDER BY Keyword
subsections.brief: Explains the ORDER BY keyword for sorting query results in ascending or descending order.

subsections.title: SELECT DISTINCT
subsections.brief: Explains the DISTINCT keyword for retrieving only unique values from a column.

subsections.title: The WHERE Clause
subsections.brief: Explains the WHERE clause for filtering query results based on specified criteria. Covers various operators, including LIKE, IN, and BETWEEN.

subsections.title: Wildcards
subsections.brief: Explains the use of wildcards with the LIKE operator for pattern matching in queries.

subsections.title: AND & OR Operators
subsections.brief: Explains the use of AND and OR operators for combining multiple conditions in the WHERE clause.

subsections.title: SELECT TOP Clause
subsections.brief: Explains the TOP clause for limiting the number of rows returned by a query.

subsections.title: Alias
subsections.brief: Explains the use of aliases to give tables or columns temporary names in queries.

subsections.title: Joins
subsections.brief: Explains the concept of joins for querying data from multiple tables based on relationships between columns. Covers different types of joins, including INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN.

sections.title: SQL Scripts
sections.brief: Explains SQL scripts, which are collections of SQL statements. Covers using comments, variables, built-in global variables, and flow control statements.

subsections.title: Using Comments
subsections.brief: Explains how to use single-line and multi-line comments in SQL scripts.

subsections.title: Variables
subsections.brief: Explains how to declare and use variables in SQL scripts.

subsections.title: Built-in Global Variables
subsections.brief: Explains built-in global variables, such as @@IDENTITY, and their uses.

subsections.title: Flow Control
subsections.brief: Explains flow control statements in SQL scripts, including IF-ELSE, WHILE, CASE, and CURSOR.

sections.title: Views
sections.brief: Explains database views, which are virtual tables based on the result-set of an SQL statement. Covers creating and using views, and demonstrates the graphical designer for creating views.

subsections.title: Using the Graphical Designer
subsections.brief: Demonstrates how to create views using the graphical designer in SQL Server Management Studio.

sections.title: Stored Procedures
sections.brief: Explains stored procedures, which are precompiled collections of SQL statements. Covers creating and using stored procedures with and without parameters, handling existing stored procedures, and using NOCOUNT ON/OFF for performance.

subsections.title: NOCOUNT ON/NOCOUNT OFF
subsections.brief: Explains the use of SET NOCOUNT ON and SET NOCOUNT OFF for improving the performance of stored procedures.

sections.title: Functions
sections.brief: Explains SQL functions, both built-in and user-defined. Covers aggregate and scalar functions, string functions, date and time functions, mathematics and statistics functions, and creating user-defined functions.

subsections.title: Built-in Functions
subsections.brief: Explains built-in SQL functions, including aggregate and scalar functions, and provides examples of common functions.

subsections.title: User-defined Functions
subsections.brief: Explains user-defined functions and how to create and use them. Compares stored procedures and functions.

sections.title: Triggers
sections.brief: Explains database triggers, which are code automatically executed in response to certain events on a table. Covers creating triggers, using the INSERTED and DELETED tables, and provides an example of a trigger for validating phone numbers.

sections.title: Communication from other Applications
sections.brief: Discusses the importance of database communication from other applications and programming languages. Covers ODBC and connecting to SQL Server from Microsoft Excel.

subsections.title: ODBC
subsections.brief: Explains ODBC (Open Database Connectivity), a standardized interface for accessing databases from different vendors.

subsections.title: Microsoft Excel
subsections.brief: Describes how to retrieve data from SQL Server into Microsoft Excel.

sections.title: References
sections.brief: Provides a list of references, including websites and books, for further learning about SQL Server and related topics.
